title: De Blasio's defense of hotel special permits complicated by history
text:
Mayor Bill de Blasio has argued that hotels have such a dramatic impact on a surrounding neighborhood that it requires more oversight | Ed Reed/Mayoral Photography Office De Blasio's defense of hotel special permits complicated by history

Mayor Bill de Blasio insisted on Friday that his recent embrace of a citywide rule restricting hotel development has nothing to do with a lifeline presidential endorsement from a union that has backed the policy for more than a decade.

“That’s ridiculous,” he told WNYC’s Brian Lehrer, who asked him about allegations of a quid pro quo during his weekly interview Friday morning. “We make decisions on the merits and I think this is just plain good policy and it should be used in all parts of the city.”

Story Continued Below

But the events surrounding the obscure land use protocol tell a different story.

After de Blasio took office in 2014, the Hotel Trades Council began pushing the policy, which would require hotel developers across the city to go through a rigorous public approval process. For the first two years of the mayor’s tenure, a political operative working for the union repeatedly emailed top administration officials to argue for a citywide restriction.

Responses from City Hall were noncommittal at the time. And by the time the union official left his job in September of 2015, the policy remained on the union’s wishlist.

Three years later, the city had put a limited version of that initiative in place in several neighborhoods and had just approved the measure in manufacturing areas. At the time, even attorneys studying the issue for the union were skeptical that the de Blasio administration would back a citywide restriction without further prodding. The problem? Officials did not seem to have a plausible reason for doing so.

“The city recently approved a zoning change that will require special permits for hotels in all manufacturing zoning districts,” the lawyers wrote on Dec. 4, 2018, to the Hotel Trades Council, according to a memo obtained by POLITICO. “The city has stated, however, that it doubts there is a land-use rationale for a citywide special permit use requirement. What reasonable land-use rationales can be developed?”

It wasn’t until the Hotel Trades Council endorsed de Blasio’s long-shot bid for the White House this year — and then pumped enough money into his campaign coffers to account for 70 percent of his donors — that the mayor publicly backed the policy citywide and instructed his Department of City Planning to study it.

The union has lobbied for the change for more than a decade, arguing it would protect the city from a glut of hotel development and promote higher quality inns with better paid workers. It would, of course, also give the Hotel Trades Council leverage. Every development proposal would land on the floor of the City Council, where politicians often feel beholden to the politically powerful organization. (Speaker Corey Johnson won his leadership post with crucial support from the union.) In exchange for approving an application, lawmakers would likely demand that a project be staffed with HTC workers.

Whether or not de Blasio privately supported the citywide policy, he never put it into practice — something that would have put him at odds with high-ranking officials in his administration, including former Deputy Mayor Alicia Glen and former Planning Chairman Carl Weisbrod. Instead, de Blasio has defended his recent backing of the rule as the obvious conclusion of having required hotel special permits in several individual rezonings, including East Midtown, along with industrial areas.

“This is a policy that we have been moving for in stages," he told NY1 last month. "And I think it’s a very community-friendly policy.”

The outcome thus far has been to bring hotel construction to a standstill. To date, nobody has filed a special permit application to build a hotel in the rezoned areas, according to a city official and a land use attorney who studies the matter. And that dearth of permits dates back to three neighborhood rezonings in which former Mayor Michael Bloomberg instituted the special permit policy, beginning in 2008.

De Blasio has argued that hotels have such a dramatic impact on a surrounding neighborhood that it requires more oversight. “When a hotel comes in, you’re talking about a lot more activity, vehicular traffic, folks staying in the hotel. It has an impact that’s different than a residential building for example,” he said during the August NY1 interview.

But he has supported arguably more consequential development without a public approval process, such as 90 new homeless shelters, the scuttled Amazon headquarters, private development on public housing land and, in the Lower East Side of Manhattan, four high rises.

The only hotels that appear to consistently generate community opposition are those that are used to house homeless New Yorkers — and those have received exemptions from the special permit policy.

"In a city where everybody opposes everything, it's notable that hotels actually have not attracted a lot of NIMBYism lately," said Stephen Smith, a co-founder at investment and brokerage firm Quantierra. "For an administration that has spoken out against NIMBYism, it seems a bit hypocritical to be contributing to it in a way that not even the NIMBYs are asking for."
